description.text:
The Garage Shield attached to the lifting arm of an automatic garage door opener. It compliments Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1765850 when used together. The Shield deflects a wire hook used by a person trying to actuate the Emergency Release Lever from outside your garage.

The Shield is held in place by a #10 X 1" long machine screw (or 4mm X 25mm), washer, and nut. (I used a nyloc nut to keep from loosening over time.) Tighten the hardware enough to squeeze the tabs on the lifting arm.

This is designed for a Lift Arm that is 1.02" (27mm) wide by .26" (6.6mm) thick.

Watch this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nDw8DOblGB8

Be proactive and protect your belongings.

title: Da Vinci Jr Dual Extruder Bracket Upgrade

description.text:
Dual mounting bracket that adds an E3D V6 or Lite6 to an XYZprinting Da Vinci Jr for full dual extrusion.

Please note that you MUST upgrade your board and firmware to something like RAMPS 1.4 in order to support this! This will NOT work with the stock XYZprinting firmware! For more information see my thread on Soliforum about my conversion: http://www.soliforum.com/topic/15273/howto-convert-da-vinci-jr-to-ramps-14/

You also will need an additional bowden extruder and extruder stepper motor. I used the 3maker All-metal for my mod, but the choice is yours.

Printer:

Hacked Da Vinci Jr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The included model and SCAD files have "legs" that extend the height of the mounting bracket to the full height of the DVJr's quick connect carriage. These are not necessary. You may adjust your slicer settings to omit the bottom of the model up to the DVJr mounting blocks.

You must print with supports. There are many overhangs on both sides that need to be supported. I used pillar supports with a 0.3mm interface in Slic3r.

Clean up the supports, disassemble your stock hotend, attach it and the new E3D to this bracket. Clip it in, wire it up, configure your firmware and test it.

The DVJr hotend can be adjusted up and down for fine-tuning your Z settings to match the E3D hotend (which is fixed in place for ease). Loosen the mounting screws just slightly and use a little pressure to move it in tiny increments, then re-tighten the mounting screws.

Final X/Y calibration is tricky and will depend on your individual printer. I ended up with X:35.5mm and Y:2.7mm as my offset, which should give you a good ballpark to start working from.

This is a topographic model of a region in southeast Asia called the Bolaven Plateau, located in the south of the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR / Laos). The model was derived from a digital elevation model (DEM) raster that was modified using a free open source geographic information system (GIS) software platform: QGIS. An open source plugin, DEMto3D, that runs on top of QGIS (or on top of another open source GIS platform: Kosmo) allowed conversion from DEM raster format to STL format.

The scale of this topographic model is 1:100,000,000. Elevation values are exaggerated by a magnitude of five (5) to accentuate the pronouncement of this large plateau/tableland feature in mainland southeast Asia.

Additional details on this project can be found at: https://matthewtoro.com/2016/09/08/topographic-3d-printing-the-bolaven-plateau-laos/

description.text:
In all of Thingiverse, I couldn't find a single Thing that was compatible with the Vertibloom hanging planter system.

This is a Customizer for generating your own Vertibloom-compatible container. Currently it supports generating a closed container, or one with draining holes, of almost arbitrary height and size. You can even customize how many hanging pegs you want to use, and how high up to put them.

To keep the thing compatible with the Vertibloom system, leave the clip_*_spacing, clip_lock and clip_stem parameters alone.

Included are two models for large pots, one with drainage holes, another without. Please note that the drainage holes do not currently include a lower tray to catch the drips, so use them with caution. I may add a tray in a future update.

Printer:

Hacked Da Vinci Jr/RAMPS 1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 for a good finish, 0.3 for quicker printing

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

If trying to minimize supports, you might want to set the brim_height to 0 to eliminate the overhangs. Also, avoid making the basket_scale parameter too large for basket_height to keep the sloping side nearly vertical.

print_settings.Notes:: Make it have lots of shells -- that will force it to print lengthwise, creating a smooth hair stick that doesn't hurt when inserted.

description.text:
A simple hairstick: print the stick, the connector piece, and the top piece. Push all 3 pieces together, glue if necessary. If you make sure your slicer creates long tool paths on the stick part, the hair stick is quite smooth and not "ouchy" when inserted. You can put any topper on it you desire - just put a cylindrical hole in the bottom of your object that measures 5mm diameter by 10mm tall.

comments.text: Awesome! But can you explain what the diagonal bar in the middle is for?
comments.author: rrichey

comments.text: It's a method for a "camera follow". As the camera moves across the length of the slider, the camera will pivot or turn slowly if the middle tube is not parallel to the other two tubes. Adjust the angle of the middle tube and you adjust the amount of "following". Done right, and the camera will keep an object in the center of the frame as the camera moves along the slider. It'll take a lot of trial and error to nail down, but it's cool trick to employ.

description.text: Remixed several designs to create this LED candle holder. Simply print both parts and glue together...

Was using some old boxes to lift my monitor up to the level I liked it. Dawned on me that I could simply MAKE ONE!

Biggest problem with this design is the amount of material used and the bridging on the bottom of the top platform.

Using supports helped the bridging to a point where I was ok with it.

Printed 4 of these and used 2 part epoxy to glue them together. Add some surface grip pads like:

https://www.amazon.com/SoftTouch-Self-Stick-Non-Slip-Surface-Grip/dp/B000SL0KJC/ref=pd_sim_201_6?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=2ERE8YWG2C13HD0VKNFT

and you are all set.

comments.text: Why not just print the top as a separate piece so that you don't have to worry about bridging
comments.author: dragoonmc

comments.text: That is a fair question. I did not want to have anything else to glue and I did not want to compromise the structural integrity of having single pieces. That being said, a monitor is not that heavy and probably does not warrant such a concern. Good suggestion.

author: Mooffyman13

description.text:
The first almost completely textured model of Moses I’ve successfully created. Others were missing textures from the top or rear.

I am surprised at how well this model turned out since all the photos (about 340+) were shot with the standard Apple Camera app on my iPhone 6 Plus. It helped that I had a deeply overcast sky to even out the exposures. I also had a lot of help using a 12-foot painters pole and my Apple Watch to remotely fire the camera. I looked silly to the passing students and staff, but the result is satisfying.

I've included a handful of photos of the original bronze that I modeled from. I have a total of 348 JPG photos covering nearly the entire sculpture available upon request for free.

I used a 12-foot painters pole with an old Pentax film camera attached to it. I taped my iPhone 6 Plus to the rear of the Pentax with blue painters tape.

With my Apple Watch I was able to remotely trigger the Camera app as I raised and lowered the pole, carefully walking around the sculpture multiple times. I probably took shots from nearly the same angles several times and certain parts like the head, the beard, the feet, etc, were photographed more heavily than other parts due to the complexity or detail.

As you look at the photographs of the bronze model, you can understand why it is not easy to get complete shots of Moses from the far rear, especially where his upper back and shoulder blades almost touch the aggregate concrete slab standing behind him and his pedestal.

After running out of battery on the Apple Watch, I wrapped up my session with some more handheld shots of the overall figure. At home, I removed any blurry shots resulting from the pole moving. As these were out of the camera JPG photos, there was really no processing them as the JPG is a very lossy format. As a last step, I stripped out the location data in the EXIF as that tends to confuse Photoscan when the photos are taken so closely together.

I then started out using 348 photos in Agisoft Photoscan. I initially started with the 'low' quality settings from matching through point cloud, dense point cloud, meshing and finally texture.

Once I was satisfied that the photos would work, I started over at the 'medium' setting. Upon completion of the mesh stage, I then used the model as a mask on the photographs. Once Photoscan was finished masking all the photos, I then started over once again but in the 'high' quality setting. The model took all night and into the late morning to finish rendering but the result was deeply satisfying.

With the exception of a butterfly shaped region on the upper shoulder blades of Moses and the rear of the backwards-projecting right arm holding the tablet, the entire sculpture was rendered and textured with little need for further intervention. Since I didn't want to share a model with holes in it as I had in earlier version, I exported the mesh into Meshmixer to fill the holes and smooth out the odd artifacts here and there on the model. I then imported it back into Photoscan and recreated the texture map once again.

At that point, the model was as closely finished as I could make it with my low skill set in modeling. I plane-cut the bottom of the model to make it level for printing in the STL file.

I exported Moses in a variety of formats hoping that the texture map would be copied intact. So far the only file that I can see that achieved this was the DAE file. For some reason the PLY and the OBJ files didn't preserve the texture map.

If anyone would like to access all my Moses photos to try modeling him themselves, please get in contact with me. I'd be happy to share them for free. I'm curious to see what the results would look like when other people work with my photos, especially in other software. Since I'm on a Mac and not very tech-savvy, using open source software like SFM hasn't worked for me, nor do the many more choices that only run in Windows at this time. If wanted, I can share my photos as an archive in Dropbox.

comments.text:
Moses is kind of like your Muse :-)
Awesome result, it looks so nice. Well done!

description.text:
I designed this Mobile to bolt onto the side of my sons cot. The reference cot is an IKEA unit with top rail dimensions of 20mm x 35mm. Depending on the bolt length you use it could fit taller rails, but the OnShape files are available for you to modify freely. I rounded all the edges on the bottom bracket to make it safer.

The part "Gantry Base/Top Clamp" is the bottom section of the gantry and the top clamp combined, the tolerance between the two creates a contained bearing/rotational point, I printed this with a BigBox Pro with minimal supports and the bearing works smoothly (I had to use a fair bit of force to free it after printing). This allows you to rotate the unit away from the cot.

Hardware required (See attached photo):

2 x M4 Cap-head bolts (I used 30mm long ones)
2 x Flat nuts (These might not be required as there is enough "bite" in the bottom clamp)

The gantry sections require some glue (I didn't bother with fancy joints for this section. The center hanging piece uses dovetail joints (May also require glue) and requires 5 of the Baby Mobile - Arm 1 pieces.

OnShape files: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/eb4c23f1efeecfa3e56b22d7/w/21289a410a44bcda0ef8227c/e/e35dbc96f0c1f60dcd96a719

Let me know if I missed anything :)

Printer:

BigBox Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Used Simplify 3d with standard settings for my printer. Printed in PLA. Supports only really required for the top clamp (Under the clamp and some around the bearing area overhang).

description.text:
This is a Micromajig that I am currently modelling from the TCG The Spoils. Please be aware I have only completed the head and body at this point. I will be completing the rest of the body in the near future but they may not be compatible with the current model depending on how I decide to join them. I just uploaded the model early because I think it prints nicely and looks cool just as it is.

Let me know what you think!

Supports:

No

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

I have printed my test at 0.2 resolution which looks good. Any higher may reduce the quality of the smaller details but I haven't tested that resolution yet.

The pin to join the head and body is quite tight, so just be patient when joining them as it may take a little force. I made it this way to avoid having to glue them, and it allows the head to swivel once they're together :)

Notes:

The diagonal struts tended to warp upwards if they were cooling too fast. I had to turn the cooling fan speed down by about 30% to fix this. Besides that, it prints out marvelously!

I remember it vividly...

I was standing on the edge of my toilet hanging a clock, the porcelain was wet, I slipped, hit my head on the sink, and when I came to I had a revelation! A vision! A picture in my head! A picture of this!

-Work in progress- Version 1

I am attempting to reverse engineer the two couplers for the Saitek X-55 Rhino Flight stick to allow a length of pvc pipe between them. This will hopefully replicate some of the feeling of a Heli Cyclic control.

23/9 - The current files uploaded work but still require some tweaking. Some of my design decisions need to be reviewed as it is quite tricky to assemble and the pins don't sit as well as i'd like.

The current version is designed around a PVC pipe with an ID of 38mm. This is what I had on hand but will probably change the design to fit a smaller ID. With the 38mm pipe I had issues with heating and bending, it wanted to crease and crack with the sharper bends (As you can see in the photo I didn't even bother painting it). The use of 90 or 45deg fittings will work but adds bulk.

The pins i used for both ends

OnShape files

Thoughts

The 40mm PVC was hard to bend neatly. It wanted to crack and fold. I've had better success with 20-25mm PVC. This could have been done with 90deg fittings but didn't have any on hand.

Rough and ready test of concept Placing the pins into their respective slots. Longer lengths allow easier fitting. Take note of the colours and their respective position. I used a transparent piece of plastic to write these down, then it's just a matter of flipping it over to get the order of the pins for the other end. A completed fitting. Completed fitting. This still requires some glue to hold the orange piece in place. The PVC Pipe I measured and tested with. 10 core cable. I pre-soldered all the cores and the pins. I had a little hole in the bench and did each pin this way. Some test pieces.

description.text: Turn a plastic drinks bottle into a bird feeder that holds seeds and nuts etc.

I used AtomKemp's soda bottle rocket kit to get a perfect cap and turned it into this thing using Sketchup.  
Poke a couple of holes through the sides of your bottle at the bottom and then use a bit of an old wire coat-hanger bent into a U shape with the ends bent into little hooks as a hanger.  
Fill your bottle with seeds, screw on the cap, quickly turn it upside down and hang it from a tree branch.

print_settings.Notes:: Print at exactly 0.2mm layer thickness so that the blank space underneath the spring prints properly.  Also make sure that the spring section is fully fused without any line separation.  I recommend printing in PLA as ABS may not have enough stiffness.

description.text:
Sometimes business is a knife-fight. This spring-loaded business card case deals your card in a flash while the other guy is still fumbling with his wallet. Push your card out nice and easy, or snap it out with panache. Either way, you'll close the deal.

Holds about 20 business cards. (Standard American 3.5" x 2")

Watch it in action: https://youtu.be/wHK3hb5xk-0

UPDATE (12/17/16): I've improved the friction lock that holds the bottom part in place.
I've also uploaded the Solidworks files for anyone who wants to hack on it.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print at exactly 0.2mm layer thickness so that the blank space underneath the spring prints properly. Also make sure that the spring section is fully fused without any line separation. I recommend printing in PLA as ABS may not have enough stiffness.

First use an X-acto knife to gently liberate the tabs and spring section from the rest of the top. Then remove the built-in supports on the exit slot. Take the leaf springs and press them into place in the slots in the bottom. Then press the slot cover piece into place. Finally, press the button piece into place. The button is not quite symmetrical, so orient it so that you get the most travel out of the button.

To load, first drop your cards (up to 20) into the top part. Slide a couple of cards about half-way out towards the back and then compress the leading edge of the leaf springs against those cards as you slide the bottom on. Make sure the bottom is completely seated into the top.

comments.text: I have seen a  few comments about the "leaf" springs losing their "oomph" after some time.  I wonder about printing them in PETG to give a little more springy action?
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text: PETG is a lot less stiff than PLA, so your springs wouldn't have much oomph to begin with.   The real problem is that most plastics creep over time - a process aptly called plastic deformation.  Plastic springs eventually poop out in any application where they are under continuous load.  So unless you only fill your card case when you want to use it (hardly useful), you are ultimately destined to a life of replacing your card case springs every so often.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text:
I see what you mean. I was thinking that PETG being a little more "springy" might hold its shape better over time but maybe it has to much give in it.
Just a thought. Thanks for the feedback.

comments.text:
Ok, I printed this in PLA. It came out flawless and the parts fit great (some parts required hot glue because their tolerance wasn't tight enough). However, when the case is full of business cards and you leave it that way for a few hours, then the 3 springs that push against the business cards simply lose their... spring. They become more flat, and if you have only a few cards left, then there isn't enough sprint to push the cards all the way to the top, which means that obviously the entire mechanism stops working. I think these springs need to be at least twice as thick (I don't think they would break if you bend them that much), or it needs a different spring design.
Otherwise, great design.
comments.author: mza1979m

comments.text: How much and how fast the PLA leaf springs creep depends a lot on the ambient temperature.  Try experimenting with scaling the X axis of the springs to make them thicker and see how they work.  If you get them too thick, it will create too much friction and it will be difficult to feed the cards.

comments.text: Yeah, it is a little tricky.  Start by freeing the little tabs on either side of the slider bar - you can use a little more force on those.  Then work back & forth along each wiggle of the spring, moving from the tabs to the front wall.  The trick is keeping the angle of the knife as low as possible. comments.text: I think my printer might be extruding too much because the slots for the springs and buttons are a bit small and the curved gaps all molded together. what size print nozzle did you use?
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: My Makergear has a 0.35mm dia nozzle, but I've set the print line width to 0.45mm.  I would imagine that a 0.4mm nozzle should work OK, but if your nozzle is larger, then details could get rounded over.  Try lowering your extrusion multiplier by 5% or so.  That'll also help with separating the spring from the surface below. Also try printing slower - that almost always helps. There's no doubt, though, that this is a bit of a tricky thing to print with all the fine details.

description.text: The "thing" here are squares on the City of Berlin to customize the Candle Holder 99GoodReasons here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1767269

There are 99Good Reasons to lit a candle! We donate any tips provided to the project -> Unesco - help for children.

The "thing" here are squares with Halloweeen Themes. Print 4 of these squares and combine it with the tealight top and bottom piece and preferrably with the inner shade
of the Candle Holder 99GoodReasons here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1755787

You may want to use the 4 squares for the variant of the tealight, where the square will only been seen, when the candle (preferrably a LED tealight) is lit. Find it here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1767269

My C-Bot and several others I've seen are fairly tall and as a result, they can shake and oscillate due to the height and speeds at which the carriage and hot end assembly are moving. To counter this and attain higher speeds and print quality, I created an OpenSCAD design built for the customizer that allows you to create a clamp that wraps around aluminum extrusions and be secured to a wall or other secure mount point.

The customizer and design allow for a wide variety of extrusion sizes. Also include is the ability to retro fit a printer using a multi piece clamp or create a fully enclosed clamp to be installed during printer assembly. Or if you are brave and want a cleaner look, you could disassemble the pieces needed to slide a single piece clamp on.

Updates:

  • 10-17-2017:
    Added dedicated flag / switch for adding a gap in the bar for LED lights.

  • 2-8-2017:
    Fixed positioning of holes screw / bolt holes.
    Increased size of holes to better fit M5 bolts.

*10-2-2016:
Added ability to create a gap in the clamp, useful for making room for LED light strips attached to the extrusion.
Added ability to create empty space in the bar by using a X pattern for support vs a solid bar.
Added a few examples of the changes.

Code is GPL and included in the github repository for my hot end mount generator, which is also on thingiverse. Links below.

I've included a couple of sample stl files, If you happen to have a need for a 20x40 extrusion clamp that is 50mm in length, you are in luck. :)

WARNING: For proper part strength and operation, this must be printed on it's side as shown and as the stl files will be produced. And honestly that's the easiest way to print it. If you decide to live dangerously and print in vertically, you can almost be assured of layer separation if you mount it to the printer and get things rocking and rolling.

Suggested usage: Print two for every side to be secured. Secure on every side of printer if possible. You want the force of the printer to be absorbed by pushing forces, not pulling if possible. Mount the clamps on the extrusion as far out to the edges of the printer as possible, wider is better. Do not try to use a single clamp in the middle or one edge, that will either bend the extrusion or create torsional forces in the frame. My advice, two clamps per side at the edges or no clamps for a side that only allows for one. better to evenly oscillate then twist the frame.

Hot End Mount Generator: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1141659
GitHub Repository for both: https://github.com/croadfeldt/Roadfeldt_3d_hczf_mount

description.text:
The Cobra Boxmod All In One print is a simple boxmod with a pre-installed two bay 18650 tray, complimenting battery door, with several aesthetic touches such as the hood over the fire button to prevent hot e-liquid from dripping on to your hand and battery vent holes in case of emergency. Basically its made to look freaking sweet.

This version is made for a 16mm or 12mm button, 22mm FatDaddy 510 V4 Low profile, four keystone 209 contacts, enough room for a Mosfet IRLB 3034, and 4x 3mmX3mm case magnets for the sliding door.

Build at your own risk, I am not responsible for any damages this design may incur.

Building Guide: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-I3ksnipe8nQ3paUFE1Yl9sbGc

Everything is already scaled to work properly right off the hot plate as long as your resolution is highest possible (0.2 minimum).

Hope you enjoy, let me know how it goes and if you have any recommendations you feel are necessary to make it more functional please ask in the comments section.

description.text:
The bassinet we were given couldn't easily attach the 'mobile set' which we had that is designed for a larger cot (with bars).
Being a new housebound dad for a bit and with my new 3D printer for the occasion I measured up the end frame (Dimensions 21mm x 70mm) and designed a clip that latches onto it with just enough flex in the plastic to get it on and off and slide along. The mobile comes apart at the cot clip like many I believe and has a circular hole that feeds into the clip (mobile internal diameter 16mm and external diameter 20mm)

Common examples:
https://www.babybunting.com.au/boori-urbane-bassinet-almond.html
https://www.babybunting.com.au/living-textiles-musical-mobile-set-bear-grey.html

First print I have ever done in PLA which worked but felt a bit loose so I tweaked a few bits and re-printed in ABS after a bit more experience a week later.

***I guess basic disclaimer that would be the same for any device for children. Depending on how much weight you put on the mobile it can pull the clip off and have the mobile fall onto the infant. Best left hanging over the baby when supervised and turned out of the way when not. Could probably be remixed so if it does fail, fail 'out of the cot' more i just haven't got around to it myself yet.

It's also safer from collapsing inwards if the bottom clip is the longer of the two rather than the top one.    Nice design for a first try!  (saw your story on ozbargain)

description.text: 1/8th scale Spitfire Mk1 to Mk14 underwing radiator (need opposite for MK9 and later) need only this one for Mk1 thru Mk5 and Mk12.  Data is in INCHES!  Not MM!

The cute barometer relies on the constant air pressure trapped inside of the jar.

  1. Print all the pieces with 0.2 resolution or lower (Printing them with 0.3 might leave some gaps between the layers and filaments and the membrane enclosure needs to be air tight. If you have a low quality printer, it could be helpful to increase the Extrusion multiplier factor to 1.1 or something like that)
  2. Make a hole into the center of the “Barometer lower half” of the enclosure after printing. It was left un-perforated because it prints better this way.
  3. Find a small jar (between 200cl and 400cl) that has its own sealing cap. Make a hole into the cap large enough for the lower half tube of the printed enclosure to pass through.
  4. Glue the lower half to the jar cap using an epoxy resin or some thick glue that won’t allow air to escape from the jar. If everything goes well, after you seal the jar, the air from the jar should only communicate to the lower half of the barometer enclosure.
  5. Make a rubber membrane from a rubber glove or a thick balloon and put it between the two half of the enclosure. Tight the flange using M3x10 bolts and nuts.
  6. Insert a small piece of wire or a needle into the rooster’s head using a soldering station or preheating the needle with a lighter.
  7. After you mount everything together, you should have a visible movement of the needle when you hold the jar into your hands. The mild heating of the jar in this case, causes the air trapped inside to expand and to move the membrane upwards. This quick test reveals if everything is sealed or not.
  8. In order to set the scale to neutral position, open and re close the jar cap in a day with 1013 hPa atmospheric pressure

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-6SVoRh0kc

comments.text: nice job. I wonder if a bi-metallic strip could add temperature compensation. Is there a simpler way ?
comments.author: Neon22

comments.text: looks like a good build. as far as the jar and the multi million u can choose from would a small mason canning jar work or is there one that works best.this will be a fun project for my little girl and maybe one for her class room as well.
comments.author: twistedfreak

comments.text: Every jar should work the same. It should be between 200cl and 400cl. If it has a higher capacity, the needle moves more at the same pressure difference and maybe you will reach the end of the scale with only small variations. On the other hand, if you choose a very small jar, the movement of the needle could be insignificant.
comments.author: twistedfreak

description.text:
Hi my name is Benjamin, and this is my first Thing!
I am a engineering student here in Sweden and a choose to make a pivot able phone and tablet stand as my first real project. I recommend printing this in medium/normal to high with no support or raft. In the model the thread that a made are M8 on the phone holder and M7 for the screw, with this tolerance, it works perfectly printed with my printer, but perhaps if you have a more exact printer, you might want a tighter tolerance, in that case email me your measurements at [email protected] so that I can make a custom model for you! Also you might want to print the screw in a bit of a higher fill density so it doesn't break.

Update!! 2016-09-24
I have included a stopper in the files menu, print this and glue it to the table mount, this way, it will stop the phone holder to go down to low.

This is a carriage for E3d's Chimera/Cyclops ,i designed but not tested yet. Made for Vulcanus Max CoreXY 3d printer but it may be suitable for other printers too. The distance of the lm10uu's is 50mm center to center.
I plan to buy the famous E3d's dual extruder solution and then print this assembly.

I use an Inductive Proximity Sensor LJ18A3-8-ZBX so i wanted it to be compact, modular and very rigit at the same time. The sensor screws in the bottom part.

For the assembly it needs 4 zipties, 5xM3 screws at the top, and 2xM3 screws at the back of the Heatblock. Each belt of the CoreXY cinematics, can be tighten individually.

Solidworks and Stl files are available.
If you have any recommendations, leave a comment so we can improve it.

remixed_from.author: Pietrogramma
remixed_from.title: Z top mount - Geeetech I3 Pro B

title: Adjustable Z top mount - Geeetech i3 Pro B

description.text:
A number of things can get the Geeetech i3 Pro B frame out of alignment, and for me it was the tension from the x axis belt which twisted the z axis screw and guide.
You can solve those problem in other ways, but I found that an adjustable z top mount was the simplest.
You probably only need this on one side, but I made two just because it looked good :)

Included is a version similar to the original part, and one version for a 608zz ball bearing, reducing friction from the spinning screw.
The ball bearing is a tight fit (I used a small vise to push it in), but there is also a hole for an M3 lock screw just in case.

The base plate and the mount are held together by a 12 mm M3 hex screw and lock nut. Washers on both sides.

Based on the very accurate part made by Pietrogramma.

Update 160913:
Added Sketchup model.

Update 160919:
Added flipped versions of the base plate (v2), which allows better prints.

title: Standard S3003 type servo in OpenJsCad

description.text:
This is just a simplified shape of a standard servo motor.  
It includes the cutout shape so you can easily include it in your own model.

Download the .jscad file and copy the servoMotor() function in your own model. An online interactive version is here:
http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/
(scroll down to Examples and choose Servo Motor) This demo merely serves to show how to use properties and connectors in OpenJsCad. The servo motor library function not only returns the shape of the servo motor, but it also defines a 'cutout shape' property and a connector property. The cutout shape can be subtracted from another solid, to make holes for the servo motor itself and for the screw holes. The connector property makes it easy to align the servo motor to a surface, without knowing the actual orientation or dimensions of the servo. Whenever the object is transformed (i.e. rotated, scaled or translated), the properties are transformed with it. So you can rotate and move the servo motor as you like and still have the correct cutout shape. For details see the documentation at http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/

author: cfudmh

title: Customiser: Air cage for MK8 extruder with pipe end

description.text:
Many fan shrouds for ventilation of the printed object exist, but none of those I looked at matched my needs: they'd not fit, feature a rigid nozzle without adjustment, block sight of nozzle and - more importantly - base layer, disallow intervention by means of a pair of tweezers or related, or are unnecessarily heavy and bulky.
In an attempt to learn from the problems with the solutions I looked at, I decided that air cage, surrounding and trapping air expelled from the cooler, and the nozzle, directing the air towards the object, should be seperate items, allowing the latter to be adjustable.
Here's now my attempt of designing the air cage, with a simple pipe end to attach a piece of flexible tube to it, which carries an air nozzle, clamped to the carrier of the extruder. A piece of wire, to bend nozzle into position, is one possible method of adjustment. I've soldered a paperclip to a crocodile clip. With the crocodile clip I attach the whole nozzle construction to the extruder. The other end of the paperclip goes to a piece of PTFE tube as nozzle, shoved into silicone hose which connects to the air cage pipe end.
This item isn't pretty - it's not really meant to be. Instead I want shape to follow function, as functional aspects bear a heavier weight to me for this application. Please consider that this implementation is still in a very early state, and improvements are not only possible, but likely too. So is it planned to replace the current flexible-tube-and-nozzle solution against a printed double hinged air duct (intended to direct air to the object from the side). As consequence are position and orientation of the opening for the pipe end likely to change to the front. Chances are also that support for a second nozzle, to point at the object from the left, will be added - but given that this should merely involve a second pipe end, or hinged nozzle attachment point, this change is likely to be a trifle. So are probably LED or camera mount points, and their respective cable guides, and given that the .scad file is provided, you can add those to the design just as easily.

Item is fully parametrised, because printers/extruders are very different, which I experienced by the difficulties finding a fitting fan shroud. Some assume that extruder carrier don't protrude from the extruder, so the cooler and fans are floating (no part of extruder below them). Others don't know how little space my extruder provides between screws and cooler, making the fit hard or impossible. And about all I looked at only provided .stl files, for which I have no decent method yet to modify, to make the design suited for my device. I'll probably stop bothering with .stl-only designs completely, and focus on those with sources provided, as a source-less design is bound to die, eventually, because lacking evolutive capabilities.

I'm not sure how much further development will be put into this design, because I currently lean towards E3D'ish designs, and consider the attempts of MK8 improvement as just an intermediate step. Replacement against a E3D bowden setup seems to me the next logical step. This design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847 by Tech2C is one which I like, with cooling of extruded filament already integrated. It comes as .stl only though, and may need some extent of redoing or convincing.

For testing the effectiveness of air catching and channeling, I apply a drop of Ballistol (that is colloidal paraffin in ethanol) on the cold nozzle, then turn on the printer. When nozzle heats up, the paraffin fumes show, by how they move, direction, turbulences and strength of air stream hitting the nozzle. A drop of melted paraffin from a tealight or candle should be adequate too.

version history

v0.0.1, 2016sep13

  • initial version

v0.0.2, 2016sep13

  • changed support to interleaved pillars.

v0.0.3, 2016Sep14

  • changed support to perforated walls.
  • lowered blocks.
  • thicker walls around air chamber.
  • added foundation to pipe end to avoid sagging.

v0.0.4, 2016Sep15

  • gave pipe end foundation more substance.

v0.0.5, 2016Sep19

  • eliminated "pillars" from air chamber variable names, changing to "wall"
  • own variable for pipe end wall thickness. rather than reusing air chamber wall thickness.
  • changed pipe end foundation to circular footprint

Needs improving:
Move pipe end up, for larger radius of air hose bend. Already parametrised, but presets put it too low. This is why the hose takes a horizontal 270° loop in the pictures, instead of vertical 180°. A downwards pointing pipe end could be an alternative. Consider using maccaroni maker http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1839527

Add 2 more blocks at top, as upper fan mounting holes constitute an air escape.

A simple door hinge that opens to at most 180 degrees rotation. Dimensions for given file are: 45mm x 34mm x 5mm hingeA/B with 4mm dowel and 4mm screw holes. Autodesk Inventor IPT file is parameterizable via the design table. There's an additional 0.2mm added to the holes so that the screw and dowel slide in easily. Likewise, for the hinge joint, an additional 0.4 mm clearance has been added to each inside edge of hingeA.

Designed in Autodesk Inventor Professional 2013 64bit (educational edition). Use the design table in Hinge.ipt and Dowel.ipt to parameterize and adjust dimensions using Autodesk Inventor. I used an iron rod of the correct diameter as the dowel - cut to size with a hack saw and grind smooth at the ends. The part itself was 3d printed at 100% infill for structural strength using ABS on a Makerbot Replicator 2X printer - heated build platform was at 120C and the extruder temperature at 230C and layer height at 0.20mm.

This is a wide angle adapter for a Logitech C920 Webcam.

The camera is touted as a wide angle but it's not really wide enough for my taste. We use this camera in my living room to Skype with family and with kids running around it never captures everyone.

I bought this lens off of Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003UKRJG0

And with this adapter it makes it's VERY widescreen. The only downside is that it will create a vignetting effect (a black circle) around the outside of the image the other people see. It's not bad and worth it for making it widescreen. It's also easy to take on/off the camera.

The lense is friction fit and is pretty darn tight.

description.text:
This thing will help you check the leveling of your 3D printer bed. It consists of the word "OK", printed in the four corners and the center of the build plate. The model is 0.2mm high, so printing with 0.2mm layer height will yield a single layer. It is adapted for a 200x200mm build plate but can easily be scaled to fit any (square) build plate.

Suggested use:

  • Level the build plate as good as possible using whichever method you prefer.
  • Print the OK test.
  • Inspect the five OKs - if any of the prints comes down squished, lower the build plate in that corner slightly. If there are gaps between the lines, raise the build plate slightly.
  • Print again. If the bed is level, all the OKs should look good.

Since many prints only use a smaller area in the center of the build plate, it is often sufficient if only the center OK looks acceptable; but if you're planning on using the entire build plate, make sure all corners look good. Also included is a model containing only a single OK, if you want to place them yourself.

I have provided a reference image showing one of the O's printed after and before calibration with this test. This was done on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2, in PLA, printed directly on a BuildTak surface.

author: larryj

description.text: made of glass or wood

This is inspired by - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7487 .

After some play, I decided I do not want the 3D print the wings. It takes ages for a large wind mill. Therefore, I decided to use 1mm thick Petg Copolyester sheets (90 cm x 60 cm each wing).

Things you will need for one mill (in all the pictures you see those materials x 2, as I've built two mills):

  • 4 X 1 meter long M8 threaded rods
  • 2 x 1 meter long M10 threaded rods
  • 2 X 1 meter long aluminium bars
  • 2 x 10 cm long square aluminium profile bars
  • 2 x 6000ZZ bearings
  • 32 M3 x 10 mm long screws
  • 40 M3 nuts
  • 6 M3 X 30 mm long (length might depend on your aluminium bars choice) screws
  • 16 M8 nuts
  • 8 M10 nuts

For one mill, you should print :

  • 16 side_wing_holder.stl
  • 2 x bearing_holder_bottom.stl
  • 2 x bearing_holder_top.stl

Check the "schematic.stl" file and photo, should be simple to understand. If not, just leave a message and I'll help.

To make sure the mill starts no matter the wind direction, I assembled two identical pieces and placed them 90 degrees (see the photo).

This is an openscad script that can generate a whistle with an arbitrary number of notes.
It isn't quite tuned right. There is a function in it to automatically calculate the length based on the note but it seems to be off by a bit.
It whistles though!

You can print the two note version in the STL that I have uploaded or you can generate a different whistle by editing the scad file. There is an array called "notes" that contains a list of of notes. They are specified as the number of half steps from middle C.
Once that array is set up, you specify how many notes there are in the array in num_notes. You can also adjust the parameters of the whistle shape by editing the constants at the top of the file.

title: Bottle flip attachment for RC drones and helicopters!

description.text:
What on earth is it?
The bottle flipper for RCs is an easy way to get 100 - meter water bottle trick-shots.

But how do i use it?
It's simple - attach a string to each of the four holes on the sides of the gizmo - then tie the strings evenly on the landing gear of your RC - now just add your water bottle by sliding it on the rail and prepare to amaze!

Will it get in the way of the camera?
No - just make sure to have 10+ cm of string just in case. This model was also designed to enable the camera to film the bottle release.

How should i print it?
I would recommend a high infill density - around 75% as the rails are under a lot of strain. It'll take at most an hour and a half to print.

NOTE: Sorry about having no picture - I'll get round to that!

description.text:
This is a modification to the Mantis Claw posted by WhiteThorn (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659427). The changes were to reduce the number of parts needed and to make assembly simpler.

Hardware needed
(20) - #8-32 X 3/4 Machine screws
(20) - #8-32 Lock nuts

(1) - 1/4 Eye bolt with at least 2" of thread
(2) - 1/4 Lock nuts

As far as screws go play around with other sizes. Where the holes are modeled at 5mm a #10 screw should work, I just use #8 because of the resolution of my printer. I've also been able to use a 1/2" long screw with a standard nut and Loctite. Use the blue Loctite if you ever want to take the screws off again :)

Update - 9/14/1016: Added a new main assembly that has a recess in the bottom big enough for a 18mm diameter washer and deep enough for a nut and washer to be completely inside so the nut doesn't hit whatever you are trying to pickup.

title: C9 PixaString Bushing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A bushing to fit DIY LED Express C9 PixaStrings to Boscoyo strips. The PixaStrings are these, http://www.diyledexpress.com/index.php?main_page=index&cPath=42_59&zenid=5a00bbca0910985b3dc1d18e83effe7e This bushing uses the Boscoyo Strips here, http://www.boscoyostudio.com/products/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=2_19&products_id=4

I have NOT tested these with the C7 PixaStrings. IF someone wants to send me one, I will modify the design as necessary.

This is a VERY tight fit. There is a small lip on the bushing to help keep it in the Boscoyo strip hole. You do have to use some force to push the pixel in. This allows both the lip and the pressure from a tight fit to hold the pixel in. A dab of super glue would make this permanent.

title: CINDERELLA (CENICIENTA) FLEXY ARM II ENABLE
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Esta solución protesica solo se podrá adaptar en un paciente niño mayor a 3 años o adulto bajo la accesoria de una profesional de la salud, terapeuta, fisioterapeuta, fisiatra y con la colaboración de un profesional en psicología

Por favor lea cuidadosamente primero el manual de seguridad y uso de esta solución protesica

Diseño del artista: Wilmer García
Concepto mecánico del Ing. Mecatrónico Christian Silva
estudiantes de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia.

Prótesis CENICIENTA FLEXY ARM II es un proyecto diseñado y elaborado por el artista plástico Wilmer A. García P. estudiante de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia y dirigido por el Ingeniero Mecatrónico Cristian Silva estudiante de Doctorado en la Universidad Nacional de Colombia. Modelo a su vez basado en el brazo Flexy de Christian Silva , El Flexy_Hand 2 de Steve Wood (Gyrobot), el brazo RIT (Rochester Institute of Technology) el trabajo del grupo e_NABLE Trabajo desarrollado por el equipo e-Nable Colombia y la Fundación Materialización 3D http://materializacion3d.com/ en Bogotá, con la participación y el apoyo de Recreartech en el proceso de escaneo 3d y la participación de Realiza3D la parte de impresión 3d. Todos estos archivos están cubiertos por la licencia creativa atribución bienes comunes. No comercial, por favor utilice la referencia de nosotros si desea imprimirlo.

Todos los padres y los niños fueron informados sobre el estudio e investigación para el desarrollo de este trabajo. Para niños de 3 a 16, el consentimiento fue explicado por el investigador principal y firmada por los niños y sus padres. el consentimiento informado por escrito de los padres se obtuvo con el fin de publicar las imágenes y vídeos que aparecen en el estudio de investigación y la investigación. Se le entrego Pautas de seguridad detalladas a los padres sobre el uso y cuidado de la prótesis de brazo.

pautas de seguridad detalladas enlace:
http://enablingthefuture.org/build-a-hand/safety-guidelines/

Los dedos están impresos en material Flexy, mano, antebrazo, brazo y demás partes en material PLA.

Para mas información sobre la Fundación Materialización 3D, E-Nable Colombia e E-Nable:
https://www.facebook.com/materializacion3d/?fref=ts

Fundación Materialización 3D / Bogotá - Colombia

This prosthetic solution can only be adapted in a patient older child or adult to 3 years under ancillary to a health professional, therapist, physical therapist, physiatrist and with the help of a professional in psychology

Please read the safety manual and use of this prosthetic solution carefully first

Design Artist: Wilmer Garcia
mechanical concept of Ing. Mecatrónico Christian Silva
students from the National University of Colombia.

CENICIENTA FLEXY ARM II is a project designed and developed by artist Wilmer A. Garcia P. student at the National University of Colombia and directed by Cristian Silva Mechatronic Engineering PhD student at the National University of Colombia. Model in turn based on the Flexy arm of Christian Silva, The Flexy_Hand 2 Steve Wood (Gyrobot), arm RIT (Rochester Institute of Technology) e_NABLE work group . Work developed by the team e-Nable Colombia and 3D http://materializacion3d.com/ materialization Foundation in Bogotá, with the participation and support of Recreartech in the process of 3D scanning and Realiza3D participation Tsen part of . All these files are covered by the common creative license attribution goods. Non-commercial, please use the reference to us if you want to print.

All parents and children were informed about the study and research for the development of this work. For children 3-16, consent was explained by the principal investigator and signed by the children and their parents. Written informed parental consent was obtained in order to publish the pictures and videos that appear in the research study and research. I was given detailed safety guidelines for parents about the use and care of prosthetic arm.

detailed safety guidelines link:
http://enablingthefuture.org/build-a-hand/safety-guidelines/

The fingers are printed on Flexy materials, hand, forearm, arm and other parts of PLA material.

For more information on 3D materialization, E-Nable Colombia and E-Nable Foundation:
https://www.facebook.com/materializacion3d/?fref=ts

Colombia - materialization 3D / Bogota Foundation
